summary: the family of natriuretic peptides exert important and diverse actions for cardiovascular and renal homeostasis. the autocrine and paracrine functions of the NPs are primarily mediated through the cellular membrane bound guanylyl cyclase-linked receptors GC-A (NPR-A) and GC-B (NPR-B) PDI was shown to co-localize on the surface of cells with GC-A and GC-B by co-immunoprecpitation and immunohistochemistry. results demonstrate for the first time that cell surface PDI expression and function regulate the capacity of natriuretic peptides to generate cGMP. PDI has dithiol-disulfide oxidoreductase activities which can reduce, oxidize, and isomerize disulfide bonds. previous studies have identified PDI at the plasma membrane of lymphocytes, platelets, endothelial cells, hepatocytes, and some cancer cells. human glomerular mesangial cells (HMCs) were cultured in endothelial growth medium (EGM-2) with supplements (Lonza, Hopkinton, MA) primary human glomerular mesangial cells (HMCs) were grown in mesangial growth media with supplements (Cell Systems Inc.) primary cells from passage 3 to 7 were used in this study. siRNA transfection HMCs were seeded in 6-well plates at 1105 cells/cm2. the next day, 8 l of siRNA or scrambled oligomers (10 M) were diluted in 100 l siRNA transfection medium. 6 l of the siRNA transfection agent were diluted into 100 l siRNA transfection medium in separate tubes. protein concentrations of cell lysates and membrane fractions were determined by protein assay (Bio-Rad) samples were aliquoted and kept at 80°C until use. western blotting was used to identify PDI in cellular proteins. 500 l of the solubilized membrane fraction containing 300 g of protein was incubated with 1 g of anti-GC-A, anti-GC-B antibodies or rabbit IgG for 4 hours to overnight at 4°C. the immune complexes were trapped on protein A/G Plus-Agarose (Santa Cruz Biotechnology), washed three times with PBS, then boiled in sample loading buffer for 5 minutes.
